key_points: Texas residents facing higher utility bills following a winter storm that caused widespread power outages.
About 2.7 million households in Texas were without power due to freezing temperatures overwhelming the power grid.
Wholesale power prices in Texas soared more than 300-fold, reminiscent of California's energy crisis in 2000-2001.
State utilities expected to increase bills to cover the cost of the price spikes and future grid updates.
Texas operates an independent power grid, leading to price spikes in electricity during demand shortages.
Concerns arise about potential market manipulation similar to the Enron scandal, though no evidence yet.
ERCOT's reserve margin has dwindled, putting pressure on generators during spikes in electricity demand.
Recommendations include reviewing how extreme weather affects generator reliability and possibly winterizing equipment.
Most consumers with fixed-rate plans will avoid massive price spikes, but variable-rate customers could face hefty bills.
Griddy, a Houston-based power retailer, advised its customers to switch providers due to soaring costs.
spokespersons: Tyson Slocum (Director of the Energy Program, Public Citizen)
Jay Apt (Co-Director, Carnegie Mellon Electricity Industry Center)
